com.snap2d.gl.opengl

Interface GLHandle

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    GL2Handle, GL3Handle

    public interface GLHandle
    Main handle object for manipulating GL data and graphics. This class serves as the primary mechanism for allocating, modifying, or drawing geometry and text, as well as allowing configuration of underlying OpenGL functions. You can obtain a GLHandle object from #GLRenderControl through a #GLRenderable.
    Author:
    Brian Groenke

                       int mipmapType)
        LINEAR or NEAREST texture filtering for texture down-scaling
        Parameters:
        filterType - linear for best quality, nearest for best performance
        mipmapType - linear or nearest; use -1 for no mipmapping

      • pushTransform

        void pushTransform()
        Pushes the current transformations to the default/current shader program's matrix. Rendering operations done after calling this method will be transformed using the transformation settings at the time of the call until this method is invoked again or clearTransform() is called to reset the transformation matrix.

      • clearTransform

        void clearTransform()
        Resets all currently stored transformation values to the default configuration (untransformed) and uploads the cleared transform to the active program via pushTransform()

      • setTexCoords

        void setTexCoords(float... coords)
        Sets the coordinates for glTexCoord2f when drawing texture-enabled geometry. Coordinates should be supplied in the glob or array as alternating x,y values - e.g: x0, y0, x1, y1, etc...

        The default texture coordinate configuration before this method is called is a regular quad texture: 0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1 (bottom-left, top-left, top-right, bottom-right)
        Parameters:
        coords - the alternating x and y texture coordinates

      • setRectTexCoords

        void setRectTexCoords(Texture2D rectCoords)
        Sets the texture coordinates based on the four corners of the given Texture2D.
        Parameters:
        rectCoords - the texture to set texture coordinates from.

      • draw2f

        Draws the buffer specified by 'buffId' to screen according to parameters set using its associated buffer properties.
        Parameters:
        buffId - the id of the vertex buffer to draw

      • draw2d

        void draw2d(int buffId)

      • putQuad2f

        void putQuad2f(int rectBuffId,
             float x,
             float y,
             float wt,
             float ht,
             FloatBuffer colorBuffer)
        Writes coordinate data for a given quad to the vertex buffer. Each successive call to this method writes an additional object into the buffer until N objects have been written, where N is the set number of objects for this buffer, or until resetBuff(int) is called. Any calls made to draw2f(int) will draw whatever number of objects are available in the buffer. Once a buffer's object limit is reached or it is reset, subsequent calls to this method will cause all of its vertex data to be discarded and restart the process.

        Note: DO NOT rely on resetBuff(int) or writing N+1 objects to wipe existing data from VRAM before draw2f(int) is called. This likely WILL NOT happen, and the previously uploaded vertex data will still be at least partially rendered. The only reliable way to do this is by destroying and re-creating the buffer.
        Parameters:
        rectBuffId - the id for the quad's vertex buffer
        x -
        y -
        wt -
        ht -
        colorBuffer - a FloatBuffer containing color data in strides of 4 for all of the vertices - if the color buffer contains fewer colors than there are vertices, the last color in the buffer will be reused. You may pass null in this argument to use the current default color set via setColor4f(float, float, float, float)

      • putQuad2d

        void putQuad2d(int rectBuffId,
             double x,
             double y,
             double wt,
             double ht,
             FloatBuffer colorBuffer)

      • putPoly2f

        void putPoly2f(int polyBuffId,
             FloatBuffer colorBuffer,
             PointUD... points)
        Writes coordinate data for a given poly to the vertex buffer. Each successive call to this method writes an additional object into the buffer until N objects have been written, where N is the set number of objects for this buffer, or until resetBuff(int) is called. Any calls made to draw2f(int) will draw whatever number of objects are available in the buffer. Once a buffer's object limit is reached or it is reset, subsequent calls to this method will cause all of its vertex data to be discarded and restart the process.

        Note: DO NOT rely on resetBuff(int) or writing N+1 objects to wipe existing data from VRAM before draw2f(int) is called. This likely WILL NOT happen, and the previously uploaded vertex data will still be at least partially rendered. The only reliable way to do this is by destroying and re-creating the buffer.
        Parameters:
        polyBuffId - the id for the polygon's vertex buffer
        colorBuffer - a FloatBuffer containing color data in strides of 4 for all of the vertices - if the color buffer contains fewer colors than there are vertices, the last color in the buffer will be reused. You may pass null in this argument to use the current default color set via setColor4f(float, float, float, float)
        points - the vertices of the polygon in world-space as a varargs

      • putPoly2d

        void putPoly2d(int rectBuffId,
             PointUD[] points,
             FloatBuffer colorBuffer)

      • resetBuff

        void resetBuff(int buffId)
        Resets the object data for the given buffer to zero. Vertex data from previous calls to #putQuad2d(int, double, double, double, double) will be discarded and overwritten upon the next call. This method can be used to reset a partially filled buffer after it has been drawn.
        Parameters:
        buffId -

      • createQuadBuffer2f

        int createQuadBuffer2f(BufferUsage storeType,
                     int nobjs,
                     boolean textured)
        Allocates a vertex buffer for rendering a given number of quads. The returned id must be stored and used in order write and draw the quad data.
        Parameters:
        storeType - a hint for how the graphics driver should treat the buffer data in VRAM
        nobjs - max number of quads in this buffer
        textured - true if this quad will be textured (so tex coords are stored), false otherwise
        Returns:
        the id for the quad buffer

      • createQuadBuffer2d

        int createQuadBuffer2d(BufferUsage storeType,
                     int nobjs,
                     boolean textured)

      • createPolyBuffer2f

        int createPolyBuffer2f(BufferUsage storeType,
                     GeomFunc drawFunc,
                     int verts,
                     int nobjs,
                     boolean textured)
        Allocates a vertex buffer for rendering a given number of polygons with a given number of vertices. Ther returned id must be stored and used in order to write and draw the polygon data.
        Parameters:
        storeType - a hint for how the graphics driver should treat the buffer data in VRAM
        drawFunc - the GL function that should be used for drawing the polygon vertices
        verts - number of vertices per polygon
        nobjs - number of polygons
        textured - true if this polygon will be textured (1 tex coord per vertex), false otherwise
        Returns:
        the id for the poly buffer

      • createPolyBuffer2d

        int createPolyBuffer2d(BufferUsage storeType,
                     GeomFunc drawFunc,
                     int verts,
                     int nobjs,
                     boolean textured)

      • destroyBuff

        boolean destroyBuff(int id)
        Deletes the VBO held with the given ID from memory.
        Parameters:
        id - the id for the buffer returned by #createRectBuff2f(BufferUsage) and #createRectBuff2d(BufferUsage)
        Returns:
        true if successful, false otherwise

      • drawText

        void drawText(String text,
            Color color,
            int x,
            int y)
        Draws text to the given screen location. If the default shader program is currently enabled, it will be disabled before text is rendered. If a custom shader is enabled, it's up to the caller whether or not it should be disabled.
        Parameters:
        text -
        color -
        x -
        y -
